title: Sudden, Fluctuating Hearing Loss Secondary to Acoustic Neuroma
chief_complaint: I lost hearing in my left ear suddenly a few days ago. I also hear a high-pitched ringing and feel pressure or fullness in that ear.

problem_summary.onset: Sudden onset of hearing loss a few days prior to the initial visit.
problem_summary.course: Fluctuating symptoms over a 3-month pre-operative period; hearing initially lost completely after surgery but showed 'late' partial recovery months later.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: High-pitched tinnitus, aural pressure/fullness, 'feeling foggy' (no true vertigo).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Functions well in everyday situations despite the unilateral issue.

history.present_illness: Patient presented with sudden mild left-sided hearing loss, tinnitus, and fullness. Over the next 3 months (July to September), symptoms and hearing fluctuated.
history.otologic_history: Initial working diagnosis was possible perilymphatic fistula due to fluctuation. Retrocochlear lesion considered because hearing never fully normalized.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal. Left ear showed fluctuating mild sensorineural hearing loss, primarily in low and mid frequencies. Thresholds varied across dates (7/3/86, 9/11/86, 9/30/86).

numeric_results.Left Ear (7/3/86): Mild low-freq loss (~30 dB HL at 250-500 Hz)

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent speech recognition scores maintained throughout the fluctuation period. No rollover.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present bilaterally at normal levels (500-2000 Hz). Contralateral reflexes present 500-4000 Hz. Unusual finding: Left contralateral reflexes were obtained at lower levels than the right.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal. Left ear showed poorer waveform morphology. Absolute latencies borderline normal, but interwave intervals and ILD were abnormal. Significant rate shift observed.

tests.name: CT Scan
tests.key_findings: High resolution contrast CT indicated a mass in the internal auditory meatus (IAM) extending into the cerebellopontine angle (CPA).

history.present_illness: Patient underwent surgery to remove 1.4 cm acoustic schwannoma.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: No measurable hearing in the left ear to pure tone or speech stimuli.

history.present_illness: 1-year follow-up. Patient reported gradual improvement in hearing several months after surgery (late recovery).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear normal. Left ear shows return of some hearing function (unusual late recovery). Sloping loss: mild/moderate in lows dropping to profound in highs.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear excellent. Left ear poor.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.key_findings: Only a readable Wave V of poor morphology was present. Latencies similar to pre-op once intensity was sufficient (90 dB nHL).

overall_audiologic_summary: This case presents an unusual manifestation of an acoustic neuroma (vestibular schwannoma). The patient, a 34-year-old female, presented with sudden, fluctuating low-frequency SNHL and normal acoustic reflexes—symptoms typically associated with cochlear hydrops or fistula rather than retrocochlear pathology. However, ABR testing revealed retrocochlear signs (abnormal ILD, extended interwave intervals, and a significant rate shift). Following surgical removal of a 1.4 cm tumor, the patient experienced total hearing loss in the ear, followed by a rare 'late recovery' of some low-to-mid frequency hearing and poor speech recognition several months post-op.
counseling_points: Explain that while the initial symptoms mimicked other inner ear conditions (like fluid fluctuation), the ABR and CT scan confirmed a tumor on the hearing nerve.
Discuss the rarity of the 'late recovery' of hearing observed; typically, hearing lost immediately after this surgery does not return.
Counsel on realistic expectations for the left ear: while sound awareness has returned, speech clarity (24%) is very poor, and the ear will likely not be useful for communication in noise.
Emphasize the importance of protecting the normal right ear.
notes_for_actor: In the first visit, you are anxious but not dizzy. You feel 'foggy' and frustrated that your hearing keeps changing—some days it's better, some days worse.
You describe the tinnitus as high-pitched and the ear feeling 'full' or 'pressure-filled'.
At the follow-up, you are surprised and pleased that you can hear *something* in the left ear again, even if it isn't clear speech, as you were told it was gone forever immediately after surgery.
